bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, August 27, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant William Dawkins, August 27, 1728, as an addendum to an ealier letter not extant, to report the arrival of letters and accounts of sales, noting his unhappiness at finding a charge of 3 per cent, the basis for which is not clear. He encloses three bills of exchange.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, August 27, 1728
div1.p: Add to Mr. Dawkins Letter Augst. 6th: 1728 Bills & Draft

Two days ago I recd your Letters under the Care of Colonel
Darnell via Maryld. One to myself the other to Colonel Page and I
Enclosing the Sale of 28 hogsheads belonging to Mr. Burwells Estate By the Baily before the
Carter left us I had your Sale of the 20 hogsheads Sent you by the Spotswood
in both these Accots. I find you have charged 3 perCt. Commission from
what hurr[...] proceeds I cant tell or what you mean by it I must
be so b[old ...] to let you know I cannot Set down Contented
under it
but this you knew from me long before now therefore pray let right be
done to these Accots: that wee may not enter into any new discords

herein Send you three first bills of Exchange Robt. Carter
Junr. on yourself for £88. Chas Fallin on Capt. John Sharp White
haven £10"17"11 Eliza. Nelmes on G. Buck of Biddiford for £3"-
which request yor. managemt. of, Two days after the Carter left us wee
had a violent Storm it was but Short She must ride it in the Bay
have heard nothing of her Since hope She recd no damage I am

closer.seg:
Sir—
Yor. very humble Servt.
per Capt: Willcox

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond. No letter of 1728 August 6 to Dawkins is extant, but a page is missing from the letter book that could have borne the letter. There is damage to the foot of the first page bearing this letter causing the loss of some words.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.

[1] This London ship was commanded by James Bradby, 1727-1732. (Adm 68/195, 70r ff., found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
[2] No information about Captain Willcox has been located.
